metadata.titleEn: Long-term glacier melt fluctuations of Qiangyong Glacier on the Tibetan Plateau over the past 2500 yr
metadata.description:
The source of the data is paper: Zhang, J.F., Xu, B.Q., Turner, F., Zhou, L.P., Gao, P., Lü, X.M., & Nesje, A. (2017). Long-term glacier melt fluctuations over the past 2500 yr in monsoonal high asia revealed by radiocarbon-dated lacustrine pollen concentrates. Geology, 45(4), 359-362.
In this paper, the researcher of Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences and CAS Center for Excellence in Tibetan Plateau Earth Sciences, Baiqing Xu, with his postdoctoral fellow, Jifeng Zhang, and collaborators from Peking University and other institutions, propose that the OPE (“old pollen effect”, the offset between the calibrated 14C ages of pollen in lake sediments and the sediment depositional age) as a new indicator of glacier melt intensity and fluctuations by measuring the radiocarbon ages of the sediments of the proglacial lake of Qiangyong Glacier on the southern Tibetan Plateau with multi-methods (bulk organic matter, pollen concentrates and plant residues). This research suggests that hemispheric-scale temperature variations and mid-latitude Westerlies may be the main controllers of the late Holocene glacier variability in monsoonal High Asia. It also shows that the 20th-century glacier melt intensity exceeded that of two historical warm epochs (the Medieval Warm Period, and the Iron/Roman Age Optimum) and is unprecedented at least for the past 2.5 k.y.
This data is provided by the author of the paper, it contains long-term glacier melt fluctuations of Qiangyong Glacier over the past 2500 yr reconstructed by the OPE.
A 3.06-m-long core (QYL09-4) and a 1.06-m-long parallel gravity core (QY-3) were retrieved by the researchers from the depositional center of Qiangyong Co. Using a new composite extraction procedure, they obtained relatively pure pollen concentrates and plant residue concentrates (PRC; >125 μm) from the finely laminated sediments. Bulk organic matter and the PRC and pollen fractions were used for 14C dating independently. All 14C ages were calibrated with IntCal13 (Reimer et al., 2013). The age-depth model is based on 210Pb and 137Cs ages and five 14C ages of PRC. Only the youngest PRC ages were used for the age-depth model, whereas older ages that produce a stratigraphic reversal and are apparently influenced by redeposited or aquatic plant material were rejected. The deposition model was constructed using the P_Sequence algorithm in Oxcal 4.2 (Bronk Ramsey, 2008). For the calculation of the offset between the calibrated pollen 14C ages and the sediment depositional age, 2σ intervals for interpolated ages according to the deposition model were subtracted from calibrated pollen ages (2σ span), resulting in the age offset between pollen and estimated sediment ages (ΔAgepollen).
This data is radiocarbon ages and the calculated ΔAgepollen of core QYL09-4 from a proglacial lake of Qiangyong Glacier.
The data contains fields as follows:				
Lab No.
Dating Material
Depth (cm)
14C age (yr BP)
∆Agepollen (≥95.4 % yrs)
Sediment Age (CE)
See attachments for data details: ZhangJF et al. 2017 GEOLOGY_Long-term glacier melt fluctuations over the past 2500 yr on the Tibetan Plateau.pdf.
metadata.instructions: The filename is: Radiocarbon ages and the calculated ΔAgepollen of core QYL09-4 from a proglacial lake of Qiangyong Glacier.xls, it can be viewed and edited by Excel software of Microsoft Office.

background: Long-term records of glacier mass changes are important for improving our understanding of glacier dynamics and for predicting the response of glaciers to future climate change. The Tibetan Plateau (TP) and its surroundings contain the largest number of glaciers outside the polar regions and have shown spatially heterogeneous glacier responses to global warming. Moraine sequences directly record ice margin change, but they are discrete low-resolution series and can be easily eroded by subsequent glacial advances of a larger extent. Multi-proxies (e.g., organic matter content, elements, and grain size) from proglacial lake sediments have been used to reconstruct continuous records of glacier change, but nonglacial processes (e.g., rainfall events, colluvial activity, and debris flows) can confound the extraction of glacial signals. Pollen preserved in Tibetan ice cores has been used to reconstruct past climate change, but no studies have focused on the effects of the melt of old ice in terms of the release of old pollen. According to a conceptual model of glacier flow, young ice containing modern pollen is formed in the accumulation area and then flows slowly to the ablation area and becomes a reservoir of old pollen. Intensified glacier melt releases more old pollen from the old ice, which, together with overridden soil from beneath the glacier, enters proglacial lakes and results in a larger offset between the calibrated 14C ages of pollen in lake sediments and the sediment depositional age.
research objective: We define the offset between the calibrated pollen 14C ages and the sediment depositional age as the “old pollen effect” (OPE). We interpret the OPE as a new indicator of glacier melt intensity and its fluctuations. We propose that the OPE can be a new indicator of glacier melt intensity and fluctuations. Sediments from lake Qiangyong Co, China, were used to test our hypothesis through comparisons of the OPE against regional moraine ages. A 2.5 k.y. record of glacier variability is presented and is compared with other paleoclimatic and paleoglacial records in order to infer spatial correlations and dynamics of late Holocene glacier change in monsoonal High Asia.
challenges: However, the above instrumental studies are limited to recent decades, and well-constrained late Holocene glacier chronologies are still sparse. Several studies have integrated sporadic moraine ages on the TP; however, some of the ages are questionable, and temporal and spatial patterns of glacier fluctuations remain unclear. Moraine sequences directly record ice margin change, but they are discrete low-resolution series and can be easily eroded by subsequent glacial advances of a larger extent. Multi-proxies from proglacial lake sediments have been used to reconstruct continuous records of glacier change, but nonglacial processes can confound the extraction of glacial signals.
methods: A 3.06-m-long core (QYL09-4) and a 1.06-m-long parallel gravity core (QY-3) were retrieved from the depositional center of Qiangyong Co (see the Data Repository for details). Using a new composite extraction procedure (Fig. DR3), we obtained relatively pure pollen concentrates and plant residue concentrates (PRC; >125 mm; Fig. DR4) from the finely laminated sediments. Bulk organic matter and the PRC and pollen fractions were used for 14C dating independently (Table DR1 in the Data Repository). All 14C ages were calibrated with IntCal13 (Reimer et al., 2013). The age-depth model is based on 210Pb and 137Cs ages (Fig. DR5) and five 14C ages of PRC (Fig. 2A). Only the youngest PRC ages were used for the age-depth model, whereas older ages that produce a stratigraphic reversal and are apparently influenced by redeposited or aquatic plant material were rejected. The deposition model was constructed using the P_Sequence algorithm in Oxcal 4.2 (Bronk Ramsey, 2008). For the calculation of the OPE, 2s intervals for interpolated ages according to the deposition model were subtracted from calibrated pollen ages (2s span) (Fig. 2B), resulting in the age offset between pollen and estimated sediment ages (∆Agepollen).
dataset: Sediments from lake Qiangyong Co, China, were used to test our hypothesis through comparisons of the OPE against regional moraine ages.
findings: Using the sediments of a small proglacial lake on the southern Tibetan Plateau, we found that over the past 2.5 k.y., a weakened OPE occurred during three historical cool periods that coincided with regional glacier advances defined by moraine ages. Our reconstructed glacier variability agrees well with glacier fluctuations in the European Alps and the global average temperature record, suggesting that hemispheric-scale temperature variations and/or mid-latitude Westerlies may have controlled the late Holocene glacier variability in monsoonal High Asia. We also show that the 20th century glacier melt intensity has exceeded that of two historical warm periods and is unprecedented over the past 2.5 k.y. This implies that current anthropogenic warming poses a serious threat to the survival of glaciers in monsoonal High Asia.

Verification.Question: Does the data collection method involve the use of pollen concentrates and plant residue concentrates for radiocarbon dating?
Is the old pollen effect (OPE) considered a new indicator for assessing glacier melt intensity?
Are the calibrated 14C ages of pollen used to calculate the offset between pollen ages and sediment depositional ages?

Disjunctive.Question: What is the primary method for dating lake sediments in glacier-related studies: radiocarbon dating, optically stimulated luminescence, or dendrochronology?
Which type of material is more commonly used for radiocarbon dating in glacier sediment studies: bulk organic matter, pollen concentrates, or plant residue concentrates?
Disjunctive.Answer: pollen concentrates and plant residue concentrates

Concept Completion.Question: What is the 'old pollen effect' and how is it used as an indicator in glacier melt studies?
Where do researchers obtain sediment cores for reconstructing glacier melt intensity, and what methods are used for dating these sediments?
What challenges are associated with using proglacial lake sediments to reconstruct continuous records of glacier change, and how do researchers address these challenges?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method suitable for reconstructing long-term glacier melt intensity over centuries?
Example.Answer: A data collection method suitable for reconstructing long-term glacier melt intensity is the use of radiocarbon dating of pollen concentrates and plant residue concentrates from proglacial lake sediments. This method involves retrieving sediment cores from lakes, extracting pollen and plant residues, and conducting radiocarbon dating to develop an age-depth model and calculate the 'old pollen effect' to infer glacier melt intensity over time.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a challenge faced when using multi-proxies from proglacial lake sediments to infer glacier changes?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge when using multi-proxies from proglacial lake sediments is the potential for nonglacial processes, such as rainfall events, colluvial activity, and debris flows, to confound the extraction of glacial signals. These processes can introduce noise into the data, making it difficult to isolate the specific contributions of glacier melt to the sediment record.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the properties of data collection methods used for reconstructing long-term glacier melt fluctuations?
Feature Specification.Answer: extracting and purifying pollen concentrates, plant residue concentrates from lake sediments, radiocarbon dating, calibrated using IntCal13, age-depth model, 210Pb and 137Cs ages, P_Sequence algorithm in Oxcal 4.2, deposition model

Feature Specification.Question: What features define the challenges faced in extracting glacial signals from proglacial lake sediments?
Feature Specification.Answer: nonglacial processes, stratigraphic reversals, redeposited material, aquatic plant material

Feature Specification.Question: What are the attributes of a dataset exploring past glacier variability through lake sediment analysis?
Feature Specification.Answer: sample lab numbers, dating materials, depths in centimeters, radiocarbon ages in years BP, offset between pollen and estimated sediment ages (ΔAgepollen), sediment ages in CE

Quantification.Question: How many cores were retrieved for the analysis of glacier melt intensity on the Tibetan Plateau?
How many different dating materials were used to determine the 14C ages in the glacier study?
What is the length of the record for glacier variability reconstructed using sediments from lake Qiangyong Co?

Definition.Question: What is the 'old pollen effect' (OPE) in the context of glacier melt intensity research?
Definition.Answer: The 'old pollen effect' (OPE) is defined as the offset between the calibrated pollen 14C ages and the sediment depositional age. It is interpreted as a new indicator of glacier melt intensity and its fluctuations, suggesting that intensified glacier melt releases more old pollen from the old ice, which, together with overridden soil from beneath the glacier, enters proglacial lakes and results in a larger offset between the calibrated 14C ages of pollen in lake sediments and the sediment depositional age.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using 'age-depth models' in glacier melt research?
Definition.Answer: Age-depth models are significant in glacier melt research as they help establish the chronological framework for sediment cores, allowing researchers to date the layers accurately. In the study, an age-depth model was constructed using 210Pb and 137Cs ages and five 14C ages of plant residue concentrates (PRC). These models enable the calculation of the old pollen effect by subtracting interpolated ages from calibrated pollen ages, providing insights into glacier melt intensity over time.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection techniques for reconstructing glacier melt intensity using radiocarbon-dated pollen concentrates compare with other methods such as moraine sequence analysis?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection using radiocarbon-dated pollen concentrates offers a continuous record of glacier changes, unlike moraine sequence analysis, which provides discrete and potentially erodible low-resolution records. Moraine sequences directly record ice margin changes, but they can be affected by subsequent glacial advances. In contrast, the pollen concentrate method provides a new indicator, the 'old pollen effect,' to assess glacier melt intensity, offering a more continuous and detailed insight into glacier dynamics.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences between using proglacial lake sediment multi-proxies and pollen concentrates for reconstructing glacier variability?
Comparison.Answer: Both methods aim to reconstruct continuous records of glacier changes; however, proglacial lake sediment multi-proxies may be confounded by nonglacial processes like rainfall and debris flows. Pollen concentrates, on the other hand, specifically utilize the 'old pollen effect' as a novel indicator of glacier melt intensity, focusing on the offset between pollen and sediment deposition ages to reveal fluctuations. This method addresses some of the confounding factors associated with multi-proxies by isolating the glacier melt signal more effectively.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies were employed in the data collection to ensure the accurate reconstruction of glacier variability over the past 2500 years?
Interpretation.Answer: The methodologies employed included retrieving sediment cores from the depositional center of a proglacial lake, using a new composite extraction procedure to obtain pure pollen and plant residue concentrates, and independently dating bulk organic matter, PRC, and pollen fractions using 14C dating. An age-depth model was constructed based on 210Pb and 137Cs ages and calibrated 14C ages, using the P_Sequence algorithm in Oxcal 4.2. This approach allowed for the accurate reconstruction of glacier variability by comparing the 'old pollen effect' against regional moraine ages.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise in using multi-proxies from proglacial lake sediments to reconstruct continuous records of glacier change, and how can they be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in using multi-proxies from proglacial lake sediments include the potential for non-glacial processes, such as rainfall events, colluvial activity, and debris flows, to confound the extraction of glacial signals. These challenges can be addressed by isolating and analyzing specific proxies that are less likely to be influenced by non-glacial processes, such as pollen concentrates, and by using robust statistical models to differentiate between glacial and non-glacial signals in the sediment records.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What underlying factors contribute to the challenges in reconstructing continuous glacier change records from proglacial lake sediments, and how do these factors impact the overall accuracy of data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in reconstructing continuous glacier change records from proglacial lake sediments arise from nonglacial processes such as rainfall events, colluvial activity, and debris flows, which can confound the extraction of clear glacial signals. These factors affect the accuracy of the data collection by introducing noise and potential misinterpretations in the data intended to reflect glacier changes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the 'old pollen effect' considered a reliable indicator of glacier melt intensity, and what are the causal mechanisms that link it to historical glacier fluctuations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The 'old pollen effect' is considered a reliable indicator of glacier melt intensity because intensified glacier melt releases more old pollen from the old ice. This pollen, along with overridden soil from beneath the glacier, enters proglacial lakes, creating a larger offset between the calibrated 14C ages of pollen in lake sediments and the sediment depositional age. This offset helps researchers infer historical glacier fluctuations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the primary reasons for the limited availability of well-constrained late Holocene glacier chronologies, and how do these limitations affect the development of comprehensive datasets in this domain?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limited availability of well-constrained late Holocene glacier chronologies is primarily due to the challenges in integrating sporadic moraine ages, some of which are questionable, and the unclear temporal and spatial patterns of glacier fluctuations. These limitations hinder the development of comprehensive datasets as they result in low-resolution series that are prone to erosion and may not accurately reflect past glacier dynamics.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the application of multi-proxy data collection methods from proglacial lake sediments impact the accuracy of glacier change reconstruction?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The application of multi-proxy data collection methods from proglacial lake sediments can improve the accuracy of glacier change reconstruction by providing continuous records. However, these methods may also introduce challenges due to nonglacial processes, such as rainfall events and debris flows, which can confound the extraction of clear glacial signals. Thus, careful interpretation is required to distinguish between glacial and non-glacial influences on the sediment records.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary intention behind developing a dataset that focuses on the offset between calibrated pollen 14C ages and sediment depositional ages?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary intention is to use the offset, defined as the 'old pollen effect' (OPE), as a new indicator of glacier melt intensity and its fluctuations. This approach aims to provide a long-term record of glacier variability over the past 2.5 k.y. and to infer spatial correlations and dynamics of late Holocene glacier changes in monsoonal High Asia.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to implement multiple proxies in the collection of data from proglacial lake sediments to reconstruct glacier changes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Implementing multiple proxies is important because it allows for the reconstruction of continuous records of glacier change, overcoming the limitations of discrete, low-resolution moraine sequences that can be eroded by subsequent glacial advances. This approach helps in extracting glacial signals while accounting for nonglacial processes that may confound the data.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives guide the use of a new composite extraction procedure for obtaining pollen and plant residue concentrates in glacier melt research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to achieve relatively pure pollen concentrates and plant residue concentrates from finely laminated sediments, which can then be used for independent 14C dating. This allows for a more accurate calculation of the age offset between pollen and sediment ages, providing insights into the glacier melt intensity over historical periods and its fluctuations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What composite extraction procedure could be used to isolate relatively pure pollen concentrates and plant residue concentrates from finely laminated sediment samples?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the field of studying glacier melt intensity over the past 2500 years, a composite extraction procedure was utilized to isolate relatively pure pollen concentrates and plant residue concentrates (PRC; >125 μm) from finely laminated sediments. This involved retrieving sediment cores from the depositional center of a lake and using a new composite extraction method to obtain the required materials for radiocarbon dating.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approach could be applied to calculate the 'old pollen effect' as an indicator of glacier melt intensity?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To calculate the 'old pollen effect' (OPE) as an indicator of glacier melt intensity, one could subtract the interpolated sediment deposition ages from the calibrated pollen ages. This involves using 2σ intervals according to the deposition model to determine the age offset (∆Agepollen) between the pollen and estimated sediment ages, providing insights into past glacier melt fluctuations.

Enablement.Question: What methods have enabled the accurate reconstruction of ancient glacier melt intensity using proglacial lake sediments?
Enablement.Answer: The use of radiocarbon dating on plant residue concentrates and pollen concentrates extracted from lake sediments, along with the calibration of 14C ages using IntCal13, has enabled the accurate reconstruction of ancient glacier melt intensity. The innovative 'old pollen effect' serves as an indicator of glacier melt intensity fluctuations.

Enablement.Question: What factors have contributed to the development of a new indicator for glacier melt intensity based on pollen age discrepancies?
Enablement.Answer: The development of the 'old pollen effect' as a new indicator is attributed to the realization that intensified glacier melt releases old pollen from glacier ice, leading to larger offsets between calibrated pollen 14C ages and sediment depositional ages. This understanding was facilitated by comparing these offsets with regional moraine ages.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in accurately reconstructing long-term glacier melt intensity over the past millennia using lake sediments?
Expectation.Answer: Nonglacial processes such as rainfall events, colluvial activity, and debris flows can confound the extraction of glacial signals from proglacial lake sediments, creating challenges in accurately reconstructing long-term glacier melt intensity.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected reasons that could lead to the development of a new indicator like the 'old pollen effect' for understanding glacier melt fluctuations?
Expectation.Answer: The 'old pollen effect' was developed as a new indicator because it reflects the offset between the calibrated pollen 14C ages and the sediment depositional age, which provides insights into glacier melt intensity and its fluctuations, offering a novel approach to studying glacier dynamics over long timescales.

Expectation.Question: Why might the use of multiple proxies in sediment analysis be necessary for understanding glacier changes, and what challenges could arise from this approach?
Expectation.Answer: Multiple proxies, such as organic matter content, elements, and grain size, are necessary to reconstruct continuous records of glacier change because they can capture different aspects of environmental conditions. However, challenges arise as nonglacial processes can interfere with the clarity of glacial signals extracted from these proxies.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how effective is the use of pollen concentrates as a proxy for reconstructing glacier melt intensity over long periods?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of pollen concentrates as a proxy for reconstructing glacier melt intensity is considered effective as it provides a continuous record of glacier variability over long periods. The offset between calibrated pollen 14C ages and sediment depositional ages, termed the 'old pollen effect,' serves as a new indicator of glacier melt intensity and fluctuations, revealing insights into glacier dynamics and paleoclimatic changes.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges do you foresee in employing multi-proxy approaches to differentiate between glacial and nonglacial signals in lake sediment data?
Judgmental.Answer: One of the main challenges in employing multi-proxy approaches is the difficulty in distinguishing between glacial and nonglacial signals due to confounding factors such as rainfall events, colluvial activity, and debris flows. These nonglacial processes can obscure the extraction of clear glacial signals from lake sediment data, complicating the interpretation of glacier dynamics over time.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the 'old pollen effect' can serve as an indicator of glacier melt intensity in this area.
Assertion.Answer: The 'old pollen effect' (OPE) is defined as the offset between the calibrated pollen 14C ages and the sediment depositional age. It is interpreted as a new indicator of glacier melt intensity because intensified glacier melt releases more old pollen from the old ice, which, together with overridden soil from beneath the glacier, enters proglacial lakes. This results in a larger offset between the calibrated 14C ages of pollen in lake sediments and the sediment depositional age.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges faced in using multi-proxies from proglacial lake sediments to reconstruct continuous records of glacier change.
Assertion.Answer: One of the challenges in using multi-proxies from proglacial lake sediments to reconstruct continuous records of glacier change is that nonglacial processes such as rainfall events, colluvial activity, and debris flows can confound the extraction of glacial signals. This makes it difficult to isolate and accurately interpret the glacial signals from other environmental and geological factors influencing the sediment record.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges involved in extracting continuous records of glacier change from proglacial lake sediments and suggest alternative data collection methods to mitigate these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in extracting continuous records from proglacial lake sediments include interference from nonglacial processes such as rainfall events, colluvial activity, and debris flows. These processes can confound the extraction of glacial signals. Alternative data collection methods could involve using multi-proxies like organic matter content, elements, and grain size analysis, along with advanced radiocarbon dating techniques to isolate glacial signals more effectively.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose a research approach to enhance the understanding of glacier dynamics using the 'old pollen effect' as an indicator of glacier melt intensity.
Request/Directive.Answer: A research approach to enhance understanding of glacier dynamics using the 'old pollen effect' could involve collecting and analyzing sediments from multiple proglacial lakes to compare the old pollen effect across different regions. This would allow for the examination of spatial correlations between glacier melt intensity and climatic factors such as temperature variations and mid-latitude Westerlies. Implementing high-resolution chronological frameworks and integrating data with other paleoclimatic indicators could provide deeper insights into glacier dynamics.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets that could be used to validate the reconstructed glacier variability over the past 2500 years and discuss methods for integrating these datasets into existing models.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for validating reconstructed glacier variability could include regional moraine ages, ice core data, and historical temperature records. Methods for integrating these datasets into existing models might involve using statistical techniques to correlate the old pollen effect with moraine sequences and regional climate proxies. This integration can be facilitated by constructing comprehensive age-depth models and employing algorithms like P_Sequence in Oxcal for chronological alignment.
